title: When will the FARC register a new political party?
preds:
Leaders of the now-demobilized FARC guerrilla group went to the offices of Colombia's National Electoral Council (CNE) on Monday to register their new political party to participate in the 2018 elections. "We made delivery of all the documentation, including the certification by the Monitoring Mechanism and the United Nations of the laying down of arms and the other documents required in the legislation," Jairo Estrada told a press conference.
http://www.worldnewsenespanol.com/309_hispanic-world/4862008_farc-former-rebels-register-party-for-colombia-s-2018-election.html FARC Registers at Electoral Council of Colombia
Bogota, Oct 9 (Prensa Latina) The political leadership of FARC registered its party at the National Electoral Council (CNE) seeking to participate in the political life of Colombia, including next year elections. At the official registration of the party at CNE, Ivan Marquez, member of the National Political Council of the Common Alternative Revolutionary Force (FARC), reiterated the party's willingness to reach peace through social justice. 'The armed conflict that wounded Colombia for more than 50 years is history', said Marquez, head of the negotiation team that participated in Havana to sign the Peace Agreement between the Government and the former guerrilla.
http://www.plenglish.com/index.php?o=rn&id=19308&SEO=farc-registers-at-electoral-council-of-colombia Colombia FARC Group Officially Registers its Political Party
https://sputniknews.com/latam/201710101058086485-colombia-farc-political-party-reconciliation/ ,

Working this Q backwards: Congressional elections set for March; what's the rush?:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elections_in_Colombia
I've totally forgotten about this question. Sh*t

@dsarin @Anneinak @Wildwood2000  Hello Raahul,  Today (5 October) we posted the following announcement to this forecasting question: Good Judgment has been asked if the Alternative Revolutionary Force for the Common People (FARC) party convention in September closes this question. While this is an important part of the process of forming a party, Good Judgment has not seen evidence to suggest they have registered. A recently released message by the FARC indicated in mid-September the paperwork for formal registration was still being worked on and while most coverage points to registration happening in the near future, none of them confirm registration. Please let us know if you have any further questions.  Best,
Heron The six non-voting delegates who will represent the FARC rebel group in the Colombian Congress under the peace agreement signed last month went to the offices of the National Electoral Council on Thursday to formally inscribe the group Voices of Peace and Reconciliation as a political movement. Registration is the first step toward becoming a legal political party.
http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/12/16/colombias-farc-takes-first-step-toward-forming-political-party.html The former rebels officially changed their name to the Revolutionary Alternative Force of Colombia, maintaining the acronym that has identified the group for more than five decades. The new name reflects its current status as a legally-recognized political party.
https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/FARCs-New-Political-Party-Will-End-Inequality-Timochenko-20170822-0010.html Colombia: Congress Votes to Confirm FARC as Political Party 
https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Colombia-Congress-Votes-to-Confirm-FARC-as-Political-Party--20170302-0001.html Another Step Toward Peace: Colombia Senate Approves FARC Transition to Political Party
https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Another-Step-Toward-Peace-Colombia-Senate-Approves-FARC-Transition-to-Political-Party-20170427-0002.html Colombia's congress has approved a law ratifying provisions of a peace agreement that permits the country's largest leftist guerrilla group, FARC, to participate in politics. The senate voted 52-2 on Wednesday in favour of the law that provides for the "political reintegration" of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC). The group's inclusion as a legal political party was a key point of the peace agreement signed in November between President Juan Manuel Santos and the FARC. The new law guarantees the former guerrillas a minimum of five seats in the senate, and five in the lower house of congress, although the group must run in legislative elections next year to claim them.The FARC will formally become a political party at a convention of former guerrillas that is scheduled for August.
http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/05/colombia-law-farc-rebels-role-politics-170511064745893.html The Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Colombia, Jean Arnault, told the Security Council today (11 Sep) that the recent formal transformation of the FARC-EP into a political party marks the “culmination of the ceasefire” in the country.
https://www.unmultimedia.org/tv/unifeed/asset/1963/1963978/

Clarification: When will the FARC register a new political party
GJ Open Clarifications on October 3, 2017 at 9:12pm wrote: Dear Williams, Thank you for your emails regarding FARC. We are looking into it and will issue further guidance once a decision is made. Best,
Heron

https://www.elespectador.com/noticias/politica/asi-se-convertiran-farc-partido-politico-articulo-677681 " . . . .the process of abandonment of arms must be completed in order to move towards the formation of a political movement. That is why, according to the project, once the process of arms abandonment by the FARC is completed, the party or political movement that emerges from the FARC's transition to legal political activity will be recognized in full legal status. "The National Electoral Council shall record the intention of the guerrillas to become a party, and there the guerrilla shall be obliged to subscribe, in addition, the constitution, its statutes, the code of ethics, the ideological platform and the designation of their managers. "The legal status of the FARC will be guaranteed for a certain period without having to comply with conditions such as a certain number of affiliates, submission to electoral contests or obtaining a threshold of voting. This will be until July 2026, . . . 
~~~~~~~
http://www.nhregister.com/news/world/article/UN-ends-disarmament-in-Colombia-as-FARC-honors-12221953.php "In a ceremony Friday . . . the head of the U.N. mission in Colombia, Jean Arnault, said international observers spread across the country had collected a total of 8,994 firearms and more than 38 tons of explosives from the rebels. . . . 
"The disarmament process is over," said Santos after receiving a recently disabled AR-15 assault rifle that he called the "last gun" of the decades-long conflict. 
~~~~~~~ 
COMMENT: Disarmament was a necessary pre-condition for FARC. Now that its officially been completed, the registration of the party can be certified. I don't know how to forecast on this question since as far as I am concerned it should have closed some time ago. . . . 
@ErikFritzsche, @Rene, @sevedb, @cmeinel, @Khalid

I do not feel "Schadenfreude", but I had been pointing towards the fact that founding a party does not equal registration right from the outset. And as far as I can see, nobody tried to find out how the registration process in Colombia workes - at least no one did share this information, here. In essence, the first bin and the crowd's judgment was a prime example of a crowd that had been overconfident for a very long time.
Staying here until my clarification request gets a response.

Undated article reports FARC has already registered as a political party
http://www.news.va/en/news/americacolombia-farc-register-themselves-as-a-poli
The next election is in May, 2018.  They need some time to promote their party prior to the election.

http://www.elcolombiano.com/colombia/politica/consejo-nacional-electoral-revisara-requisitos-del-partido-de-las-farc-BX7246131 SEPTEMBER 06, 2017
The National Electoral Council (CNE) is waiting for the FARC to pass the request for legal status for its new party, Fuerza Revolucionaria Alternativa del Común. The entity must evaluate whether or not they comply with the requirements that are needed to certify the community.
"According to the obligations of the Peace Agreement, one of the previous steps for the constitution of the party is the abandonment of arms. This is understood as the certification that must be issued by the National Government in the head of the President - or whoever it may be - that the FARC as a party can acquire the status. At the moment it is a political grouping that is being structured according to its platform, statutes, logosímbolo, cadres, "explained the magistrate and former president of the CNE, Alexander Vega.
Vega said that once the FARC pass that request, the CNE should receive from the Government that certificate that would have to be issued by the Office of the High Commissioner for Peace.
The FARC is expected to request its status next week. Meanwhile, the ex-guerrilla group 'has been doing the homework' because, after its National Congress, which ended with a concert in the Plaza de Bolivar, it was known that the director of that party will be Rodrigo Londoño, known as Timochenko, that Iván Márquez will be the political advisor, and that Pablo Catatumbo will be the councilor of the community.
It may interest you: So the Farc voted for their leaders and "Timochenko" was not the first
What will come to review the highest electoral body, is that these appointments - which were made by the national leadership of the FARC composed of 111 people - have been carried out correctly and that the statutes meet certain parameters.
"In addition to having a logosmbol it must comply with parameters of a pluralist statutes and in that must be incorporated its ideological platform, how will be its participation for women and young people; and how will be the procedure for delivery of endorsements. That will be reviewed by the CNE, "explained the magistrate.
For the time being, the request for funding for the new party and the Center for Thought was already made, which was established in the agreement signed with the government of the President of the Republic, Juan Manuel Santos.
These resources amount to 3.6 billion pesos, which is divided by equal halves for operating expenses and said center of thought.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  It sounds like the CNE can take their sweet time registering the new party.

FARC has given itself a new name (though its acronym remains unchanged), and has had a party conference, but I'm reading that it has a leadership problem.  One strong candidate had a heart attack in July and is under medical treatment in Cuba.  Other candidates are less well-known.

"The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) completed their transition from a guerrilla army to a political party, keeping their acronym but changing their name to the Common Alternative Revolutionary Force and their logo to a red rose. Colombia’s president, Juan Manuel Santos, announced the first bilateral ceasefire between his government and the National Liberation Army, another leftist guerrilla group"
https://www.economist.com/news/world-week/21728684-politics-week

They declared their party on 2 September.  This gives them a month to "register".
[It's easy to predict the past.]

Supporters of Newly-Formed FARC Party Gather in Bogota Yahoo News UK (2017) September 2, states that: Colombia’s former FARC rebel group held a formal ceremony to relaunch as the Common Alternative Revolutionary Force on September 1, as it transitioned to a civilian political party following its disarmament. Thousands gathered in Bogota where a “concert for reconciliation and peace” was held on Bolivar Plaza, as seen in this video. Earlier, the party held its first National Congress in Botoga, Colombia, during which its delegates voted to retain the FARC acronym under the new name of Fuerza Alternativa Revolucionaria Del Común, which translates to the Alternative Communal Revolutionary Forces (para 1-3). Yahoo News UK Website. (2017). Supporters of Newly-Formed FARC Party Gather in Bogota. Yahoo News UK. Retrieved from
https://uk.news.yahoo.com/supporters-newly-formed-farc-party-055059060.html

Colombia's FARC political party looks to coalition for 2018 elections Cobb and Bocanegra (2017) September 1, state that: Colombia’s disarmed FARC rebels have their eye on forming a political coalition for the 2018 elections, ex-rebel leaders said on Friday, as the group marked its transition to a political party with a concert in Bogota’s central square. The former Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), whose political party will be called the Revolutionary Alternative Common Force, ended its part in a decades-long war that has killed more than 220,000 people under a 2016 deal which granted amnesty to most of its fighters. The decision by the group to preserve its famous FARC Spanish acronym raised eyebrows, given many Colombians associate the word with decades of bloodshed. Whether the ex-rebels can convince Colombians, many of whom revile them, to back the new party remains to be seen. The FARC will hold 10 automatic seats in Congress through 2026 under the terms of the accord and may campaign for others (para 1-5). Cobb, J., S. & Bocanegra, N. (2017). Colombia's FARC political party looks to coalition for 2018 elections. Reuters. World News. Retrieve from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-colombia-peace-politics/colombias-farc-political-party-looks-to-coalition-for-2018-elections-idUSKCN1BC62J

Colombia’s FARC becomes political party Agence France Presse (2017) September 1, states that: Colombia's FARC, formerly a guerrilla group, re-launches itself Friday as the Common Alternative Revolutionary Force, sealing its transformation into a leftist political party following its disarmament after a half-century civil conflict (para 1). Agence France Presse (2017). Colombia’s FARC becomes political party Agence France Presse. Americas Columbia. Retrieved from
http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2017/09/01/533645/Colombia-FARC-political-party Tame Guerillas: Colombia’s FARC to Launch Political Party on September 1 Sputnik News Website. (2017). Tame Guerillas: Colombia’s FARC to Launch Political Party on September 1. Sputnik International. Latin America. Retrieved from
https://sputniknews.com/latam/201709011056981157-farc-party-launch/ Colombia's FARC rebels keep famous acronym for new political party Cobb (2017) August 31, states that: Colombia’s disarmed FARC rebel group is preserving its famous acronym as it becomes a civilian political party, part of its demobilization under a peace deal with the government to end more than 50 years of war. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia rebels, whose first political conference will close on Friday with a concert and speeches in Bogota’s central square, will now go by Revolutionary Alternative Common Force, preserving the Spanish initials. Under the 2016 peace deal to end its part in a war that has killed more than 220,000 people, most of the group’s fighters were granted amnesty and allowed to participate in politics. Whether the rebels will get backing from Colombians, many of whom revile them, remains to be seen. The group had originally floated several other names, including others which kept the initials, but the new name won against New Colombia in voting at the conference on Thursday, FARC leader Rodrigo Londono, known by his nom de guerre Timochenko, said on Twitter. FARC leadership and social media accounts also posted a graphic of the party’s policy priorities and its new logo, a red rose with a red star in the middle (para. 1-5). Under the peace accord, FARC’s party will have 10 automatic seats in Congress through 2026 and may campaign for others. Both legislative and presidential elections are set for 2018 (para. 9). Cobb. J. S. (2017). Colombia's FARC rebels keep famous acronym for new political party. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-colombia-peace-politics/colombias-farc-rebels-keep-famous-acronym-for-new-political-party-idUSKCN1BB39N Colombia s FARC Opens Congress to Become Political Party Telesur TV (2017) 27 August, states that: The FARC has begun its Congress in Colombia to become a political party, after completing the disarmament plan, as part of the peace agreement to end more than five decades of internal conflict. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia began a week-long conference ending Sept. 1 with a massive public event in Bolivar Square in the historic center of Bogota. "We will transform ourselves from now on into a new exclusively political organization, which will exercise its activity by legal means. Rodrigo Londoño, also known as Timochenko, and top leader of the FARC said during the opening. "This does not mean that we give up our ideological foundations or project of society. "It is not a matter of longing to turn our eyes to the past but to draw from it the experience with aiming to build a better future for our people," Timochenko said. The leader who reportedly arrived a week ago from Cuba, where he had undergone medical treatment, said that the event was historical, since it was the first public congress by the organization, and it was held in the capital (para. 1-5). Telesur TV News Website. (2017). Colombia's FARC Opens Congress to Become Political Party. Telesur TV. Latin Americas. Retrieved from 
https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Colombias-FARC-Opens-Congress-to-Become-Political-Party-20170827-0005.html

Much of the real estate listed by the FARC, which amounts to around half of all its assets, lacks any official registration, “which frankly makes it useless and inadmissible” to the inventory, Martínez wrote. As the ownership of these properties cannot be legally identified, the Attorney General’s Office has stated that “for now, none of the FARC’s real estate is immune to being seized” by authorities

Dateline Aug.28, 2017 -- Having given up its arms as part of a peace deal with the Colombian government, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) now seeks a new life as a political party. "We are transforming the FARC into a new, exclusively political organization," leader Rodrigo Londono told supporters at a party congress meant to select candidates for an upcoming election.  -- 	Foreign Policy <fp@foreignpolicy.com>

Colombia's FARC to launch political party on September 1 As part of last year's peace deal, FARC rebels will launch a political party that provides them a platform to use 'words as the only weapon.' Yet several challenges to implementing the peace deal loom on the horizon. Reuters (2017) July 24, states that: Colombia's Marxist FARC rebels announced Monday they will officially launch a political party on September 1, a month after guerrilla fighters disarmed as part of a historic peace deal with the government.
"We have made peace to participate in politics. We said that we would abandon bullets to have words as the only weapon," FARC chief negotiator Ivan Marquez said at press conference in the capital Bogota (para. 1-2). Reuters News. (2017). Colombia's FARC to launch political party on September 1. Reuters. Deutsche Welle. Politics. Retrieved from.
http://www.dw.com/en/colombias-farc-to-launch-political-party-on-september-1/a-39820680
Good info by @ErikFritzsche and @Gibson below on how this could shake out.
Need to think on this one some more

Thought CNE's response must take 30 or fewer days. If CNE wants to drag it all the way out (not sure of their incentive) i assume this could mean the decision occurs on the first day of the second bucket. But maybe I can't count (maybe CNE's 30 days is inclusive of the filing day)? Anyone know of precedent political party registration-approval timelines at CNE? @ErikFritzsche

I am sure: Founding a party does NOT equal registration, so the question will NOT resolve on 1 September if the FARC would have founded a party at that date (see for some information on registration the link, here: http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/partidos-politicos/partido-politico-de-las-farc-103928).

What does "register" mean? As far as I know about the terms in use concerning political parties, If they would found a party on 1st September this will NOT imply registration... Founding a party and registration are distinct processes for all that I have read about the founding of political parties around the world. There exist parties who were not officially registered: e.g. some extremist or populist parties... Registration is officially used term for the official recognition of a party by the administration! As I mentioned earlier (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/529429)
* AFTER that meeting they have to register officially, i.e. the national Electoral Committee has to certify as a political party (Consejo Nacional Electoral)(http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/partidos-politicos/partido-politico-de-las-farc-103928).  This question needs clarification. A party conference where they found the party is NOT sufficient, to my mind. And it is not likely that the Columbian state will register the party before 30 September 2017, even if they would found it on September 1st... to my mind! *** I have just asked for clarification! ***

The FARC announced the party will debut 1 September (http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4725652/Colombian-guerrilla-group-FARC-launch-political-party.html, http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/colombia-s-farc-rebels-to-debut-political-party-on-september-1-9059486).

Crowding a little... :-(
In the media one can read about August, but I do not believe it... refering to my earlier comment: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/529429

The FARC and the Colombian Communist Party (PCC) are creating a political alliance to avoid having conflict among leftist candidates during the 2018 election (http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Colombian-Communist-Party-FARC-Seek-2018-Election-Alliance-20170714-0018.html). The PCC held their latest conference last weekend (13-16 July), with participation from other leftist movements such as the People's Congress and the Patriotic March.  FARC is still signalling intent to form a political party, but an alliance with the PCC could ease the time pressure of having to create a party, as they will be able to place support behind PCC candidates and focus exclusively on areas where they continue to have influence. Conversely, this development could accelerate the development of the political party to prevent the FARC from being subsumed by the PCC. Either way, zeroing out the possibility of after 1 January.

Colombian dissident FARC rebels free captive U.N. official: government Murphy (2017) July 5, states that: Colombia's dissident FARC rebels freed a member of a United Nations team it had taken hostage while he was working on a project to substitute illegal crops with legal ones, the government said on Wednesday. The Colombian United Nations contractor was seized on May 3 by gunmen close to Miraflores in southern Guaviare province, where coca cultivation has long formed a key part of Colombia's cocaine production. He was stopped by armed men in a convoy of vehicles. "The U.N. contractor kidnapped by organized crime in Guaviare has informed his superiors that he has been freed by his captors," the defense ministry said via its Twitter account. The rebels, about 300 or so former FARC fighters who rejected a peace accord with the government late last year, want to take over coca cultivation and cocaine trafficking that was abandoned when the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) agreed to lay down their weapons (para. 1-4). While as many as 7,000 fighters agreed to the pact and have turned in most of their weapons to the United Nations, the dissidents refused. They have formed a new criminal gang and now engage in the same lucrative drug trafficking that the FARC had pursued for years, the military has said (para. 6). The FARC's leadership expelled them. Opposition politicians, including former President Alvaro Uribe, are angry the peace accord allows former FARC fighters to avoid prison time and participate in national politics. Many Colombians say the government has not done enough to prevent other criminal groups and FARC dissidents from filling the void and taking over the drug business (para. 6-7). Murphy, H. (2017). Colombian dissident FARC rebels free captive U.N. official: government. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-colombia-kidnapping-idUSKBN19Q1WR
Reversing strongly based on bad health reports of Farc members  leading to possible delays, as well as other lingering questions as to procedure and interpretation
Re-balancing a little later in the year due to passage of time.

The FARC may form a political party before the end of September, but the vitriol against them right now has similarities to the slaughter of the Union Patriotica, the FARC's first attempt at a political party in the 1980's. The demise of the UP is still remembered by Colombians, and should serve as a cautionary tale about the perils of rushing into the political arena, especially considering the UP and the FARC were significantly more popular than the FARC currently is.

Colombia’s Santos: FARC weapons handover “Best News in 50 Years” Emblin (2017) June 27, states that: In a town considered a bastion of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) guerrilla, Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos attended a ceremony, Tuesday, in Mesetas (Meta) to preside over the end of FARC as a fighting force. Accompanied on stage by FARC’s top brass and maximum commander Rodrigo Londoño, known by his nom du guerre “Timochenko,” President Santos recited words by French novelist Victor Hugo written for the 1948 International Peace Congress in Paris. “One day will come when there will be no more wars. One day will come when men stop arming against each other.” The hour-long ceremony in one of FARC’s 26 transitional zones marks the end of one of the world’s oldest Marxist insurgencies, although “Timochenko” said his organization would continue in the struggle to defend the agreements of the final peace accord, signed last November in the Colombian capital. “We continue to exist. We exist as a legal movement,” said Londoño. On Sunday, FARC handed over the last of their weapons to United Nations monitors, completing a three-month demobilization process that UN Special Envoy and head of the Colombia mission Jean Arnault claimed was “honored by both sides.” “This is the best news for Colombia in the last 50 years,” said Santos to an audience of former combatants and representatives of Colombia’s left-wing political parties (para. 1-5). Emblin, R. (2017). Colombia’s Santos: FARC weapons handover “Best News in 50 Years”. The City Paper Bogota. FARC. Retrieved from
https://thecitypaperbogota.com/news/santos-farc-weapons-handover-best-news-in-50-years/17522

The 58 yr old leader of Colombia's Farc rebel group, Rodrigo Londoño, (aka Timochenko), commander of  FARC since 2011, is being treated in hospital for a stroke.  He is expected to leave hospital on Tuesday and make a full recovery.  He was admitted to hospital Sunday morning.  His health is "in a stable and satisfactory condition," doctors said in a press conference.  He suffered a heart attack two years ago when he was in Cuba negotiating a peace deal with Colombian officials. He has said he was "not nostalgic" of his days as a guerrilla in the jungle.
"I honestly feel a great relief for having concluded this stage and preparing for the next phase," . . . ”For me, as revolutionary, the weapons were simply a tool that were with us for many years. "But at the Farc we are not in love with guns. We love our cause and our ideals. And if we can carry on with our ideals without the guns, so much the better," he told El Espectador.

I don't think this will affect the process significantly, but it might slow the FARC down, as they generally like to have consensus on major issues, at least among the Secretariat (http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-40476101). However, given Timochenko is supportive of the peace process and appears to be in stable condition, it's likely the rest of the Secretariat will move forward as planned.

I'm not as optimistic as others that this is a sure thing before the end of September. While the FARC has made significant progress compared to the previous three peace processes, the road to peace and the eventual creation of a political party can be longer and more winding than we are accustomed to in the western democracies. To simply assume that the FARC has met its requirements and will be unanimously supported by the Colombian people and government in creating a peace process is to overlook the past 50 years. And while I understand that the Santos administration has committed itself to peace, let's not forget former President, now Congressman Uribe and his efforts to undermine the peace process in favor of complete elimination of the FARC through military force.  Slight increase for before October, and slight decrease for after January. Good info by @ErikFritzsche below on why January is not likely.

When will the next Congressional elections be?
* 11 March 2018
* The deadline for registration to the elections is: 11 December 2017 (http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/partidos-politicos/partido-politico-de-las-farc-103928). What role does the peace agreement play?
* FARC becoming a political party after disarmament is part of the deal, as is a specific 'Lex specialis FARC' (details: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colombian_peace_process; http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/proceso-de-paz/proyecto-con-el-que-las-farc-seran-partido-politico-45185).
* HoR voted for this law which will guarantee the FARC's political party five seats in the House and five in the Senate until 2026 - and the formalization of the participation of FARC's political party at the congressional elections in 2018 (http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Colombia-Congress-Votes-to-Confirm-FARC-as-Political-Party--20170302-0001.html).
* Senate has confirmed the bill (http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/05/colombia-law-farc-rebels-role-politics-170511064745893.html). What is necessary to register?
* The disarmament: veto player is the Colombian Gov AND the United Nations: they have to monitor the disarmament (see: http://thebogotapost.com/2017/03/31/jean-arnault-peace-implementation-needs-to-be-accelerated/). Important person: Jean Arnault, head of the UN mission in Colombia. FARC officially ceased to be an armed group at 27 June 2017; this was mostly verified by the UN and the Gov of Colombia (http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-40417207; https://amerika21.de/2017/06/179127/farc-kolumbien-entwaffnung). However, the full process is intended to be finished by August 2017, and must be certified by the UN mission (http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/partidos-politicos/partido-politico-de-las-farc-103928).
* They have to form themselves as a political party: something they scheduled for August (http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/05/colombia-law-farc-rebels-role-politics-170511064745893.html; http://www.newvision.co.ug/new_vision/news/1453048/colombia-law-rebels-role-politics).
* AFTER that meeting they have to register officially, i.e. the national Electoral Committee has to certify it as a political party (Consejo Nacional Electoral)(http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/partidos-politicos/partido-politico-de-las-farc-103928).  How long will it take for the FARC's political party - given that it will be founded in August - to be officially registered?
* Unknown!
* But it has to be before 11 December 2017 if they want to take part in the Congressional elections in 2018. And it is very likely that this will take place since - otherwise - it would blast the core of the peace deal. Given that, it seems reasonable to conclude the following:
* It is rather likely they will register before the end of the year, to be precise: before 11 Dec 2017.
* It seems equally likely that they will do so before the end of September and after September to the end of 2017. (There is some speculation if the Gov could tactically delay the registration process since it seems not very popular that the FARC becomes a political party among the voters of the Gov and president: so they may try to lead to the impression that they scrutinized them fairly well; besides this: as long as they wait the FARC's party cannot get access to public funding… - but it might be possible to develop arguments in favor of a quite fast ratification process by the Gov, e.g. to avoid the impression that FARC had to suffer too much thereby raising their chances at the 2018 elections…) What do other forecasters think?

Goodbye, Weapons!’ FARC Disarmament in Colombia Signals New Era Casey and Daniels (2017) June 27, states that: MESETAS, Colombia — As United Nations inspectors slammed shut a shipping container filled with rifles, fighters from Colombia’s largest rebel group cheered on Tuesday morning when their leader declared that they had laid down their arms after 52 years of guerrilla war. It may yet be some time before every weapon the rebels fired in Colombia is accounted for. But the ceremony signaled to the country that the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known by its Spanish initials as the FARC, would no longer threaten Colombians as it had for generations. “Goodbye, weapons! Goodbye, war!” Rodrigo Londoño, the FARC leader known as Timochenko, shouted to the fighters. The rebels have abandoned their battle camps for demobilization camps like the one in a lush stretch of countryside near Mesetas — temporary settlements of tents and drywall buildings where the rebels have been slowly handing over their weapons, 7,132 at last count. Some rifles will remain at the camps for security purposes until Aug. 1, the United Nations inspectors said, and rebel weapons caches were still being examined. But for the most part, the inspectors said, the disarmament is essentially complete.  The weapons have been packed for shipment out of the country, to be melted down and used to build monuments. Rank-and-file rebels will soon be free to trade their fatigues for civilian clothes and begin new lives. And the FARC is laying plans to become a political party, much like the parties that emerged from guerrilla groups in post-conflict El Salvador and Guatemala. The Colombian government must now tackle a host of challenges under the complicated peace agreement with the FARC, which took years to negotiate. Special tribunals are to be established to settle war-crimes cases, and farmers are to be given incentives to stop growing coca leaf. (The rebels largely controlled the cocaine trade in Colombia.) “The goal of ending the war has essentially been met,” said Cynthia J. Arnson, the director of the Latin America program at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars. “It’s implementing the 300-plus-page document, with 100 different programs and strategies, that’s going to be difficult.” Colombia’s president, Juan Manuel Santos, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize last year for the peace accords with the FARC, but the deal remains highly controversial in Colombia. Voters rejected the accords by a narrow margin in a referendum last year, with many Colombians arguing that the fighters, who were promised amnesty, had gotten off too easily. After the referendum, Mr. Santos got the Colombian Congress to approve a revised deal with FARC without submitting it to another referendum. But with his term scheduled to end next year, he has been under constant attack from conservatives, including critics who say that the FARC will not reveal all the weapons and cash it has hidden in the jungle, something analysts say is possible. The ceremony on Tuesday offered Mr. Santos a chance to remind his country that peace with the FARC had been awaited by generations of Colombians (para. 1-11). He repeated a mantra heard widely in the camp — that far from surrendering, the rebels were transforming themselves for a new, democratic fight (para. 26). “We are not demobilizing,” he said. “We are laying down our weapons to become an open and legal political movement” (para. 26-27). Casey, N. & Daniels, J., P. (2017). Goodbye, Weapons!’ FARC Disarmament in Colombia Signals New Era. The New York Times. Americas. Retrieved from
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/27/world/americas/colombia-farc-rebels-disarmament.html

A new obstacle arises: Accusations of plagiarism in the new logo https://www.kienyke.com/politica/nuevo-logo-de-las-farc-rafael-nieto This could lead to a long and costly legal battle, yet I doubt it. Hardly anyone has remarked on them forming a party through a negotiated disarmament and yet keeping the word "armados" (armed) as part of their brand.
The goverment will intentionally try to make it a long process. If they don't manage to make it in the second time window, their chances will be low after.

Constitutional court rulings impose additional layers ito time and legislative process so slows things down affecting q timeline. I don't think it really affects the likelihood but mistrust by FARC for government still touchy. http://www.janes.com/article/70600/colombian-court-rejection-of-fast-track-mechanism-for-farc-peace-accord-legislation-raises-civil-war-and-terrorism-risk

The FARC insurgency in Colombia has continued for more than six decades.  Belief is a powerful force, and the FARC rebels have been willing to execute extreme measures for their beliefs.  The unabbreviated English translation of the name of the group is the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia--People's Army.  The symbolic turnover of arms and deadlines from the peace agreement seem to be baby steps.  If I were in negotiations with FARC, the first thing I would ask is for a name change.  Having the word armed in the formal name of a rebel group is a poor way to begin a pivot to a legitimate political party.  I predict FARC will not have a registered political party for a long time.

"Colombia's FARC rebels will complete their historic disarmament on Friday, ending half a century of war, President Juan Manuel Santos said during an official visit to France. "This June 23, the United Nations mission in Colombia will announce that the FARC has handed over 100 percent of its weapons," Santos told an economic forum in Paris. "Today the FARC, the most powerful and oldest guerrilla movement in Latin America, will cease to exist," he said to warm applause. This date "changes the history of Colombia," Santos said. The 2016 Nobel Peace laureate is in France to promote post-conflict Colombia as an investment destination."

Since this is their big chance to assimilate and gain popularity, they would not risk rushing their establishment.

FARC Still Under Attack Despite Colombia Peace Accords Mac William (2017) June 16, states that: Luis Alberto Ortíz was preparing for a new life. As a member of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), he had spent his entire adulthood engaged in armed conflict against the Colombian state. Following the 2016 peace agreement between the FARC and the government of Juan Manuel Santos, Ortíz, like thousands of other rank-and-file FARC guerrillas, was to disarm and reintegrate into civil society under the terms of the deal (para. 1). With the FARC due to enter electoral politics later this year, the killings have evoked memories of past atrocities. Following the 1984 peace agreement, a new left-wing political party, the Patriotic Union (UP), was formed by the FARC, the Communist Party and other sectors on the Colombian left. It wasn’t long before the UP’s modest electoral advances elicited a brutal response from its enemies (para. 8). In what is often described in Colombia as a ‘political genocide’, thousands of UP members, including two presidential candidates, were murdered by right-wing paramilitaries and state security forces in the late 1980s and 1990s. This repression convinced the FARC of the unviability of electoral politics as a means of achieving change and contributed majorly to a sharp escalation in conflict during subsequent years. Terms of the 2016 agreement relating to political participation are designed to prevent any similar re-occurrence afflicting new political actors in Colombia. In contrast to the 1980s, there is broader support for the peace process across the political spectrum, including – critically – within a military which was central to instigating the violence of previous decades. However, with the agreement implicit that the state is responsible for post-conflict security, the government must implement mechanisms to ensure the safety of demobilized FARC members once they reintegrate into civil society. The Santos administration, meanwhile, denies the FARC is being targeted, with government officials blaming the murders of political activists on criminal gangs. This situates such killings outside the realm of political, or conflict, violence. Vice-President Oscar Naranjo said that the government ‘will not permit that these acts return as a constant feature. We are fully committed to establishing the individuals responsible’ (para. 8-11). Mac-William, N. (2017). FARC Still Under Attack Despite Colombia Peace Accords. CaribFlame. Retrieved from
http://www.caribflame.com/2017/06/farc-still-under-attack-despite-colombia-peace-accords/ The Current Situation in Colombia The U.S. Institute of Peace (2017) Wednesday, February 1, states that: The 2016 Colombian peace accord that ended one of the world’s longest-running armed conflicts is now being carried out, and the country faces the massive task of reintegrating former fighters and fostering reconciliation. The half-century war killed at least 220,000 people, uprooted more than 6 million, and left some 8 million registered victims. The U.S. invested about $10 billion in strengthening Colombia to fight the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC-EP) and suppress drug trafficking, and actively supported the peace process.
Under the deal between the Colombian government and the FARC, almost 10,000 guerrillas will demobilize, transition to civilian life, and be allowed to enter electoral politics. Preventing a resurgence of violence will require reintegrating them into society, compensating victims and returning their lands, and shrinking the socio-economic disparities and political exclusion at the root of the conflict. The government also continues to pursue peace talks with a smaller insurgency, the National Liberation Army (ELN), and faces groups of demobilized paramilitary fighters reorganizing into criminal gangs (para. 1-2). The U.S. Institute of Peace Website. (2017). The Current Situation in Colombia. The U.S. Institute of Peace. A USIP Fact Sheet. Retrieved from
https://www.usip.org/publications/2017/02/current-situation-colombia

FARC rebels to complete disarmament in Colombia Feldman (2017) Jun 20, states that: Today is the deadline for the rebel organization FARC to hand in the last 40% of its weaponry and fulfil the terms of a peace deal it negotiated with the Colombian government last year. Conflict between FARC and the Colombian government lasted for more than 50 years, making it the world’s longest-running.  Although a peace deal was voted down in a referendum last year, a modified version passed congress.  Under the terms of the peace agreement, most FARC fighters would receive amnesty while the organization becomes a legitimate political party. However, FARC only met its deadline for handing in the first 60% by Friday, 3 days later than planned.  The group hopes to make the final deadline on schedule, but logistical difficulties in transporting the weapons persist.  If FARC is unable to deliver the weapons on time, it could threaten to destabilize the fragile peace process (para. 1-3). Feldman, J. (2017). FARC rebels to complete disarmament in Colombia. Foreign Brief. Retrieved from
http://www.foreignbrief.com/daily-news/farc-complete-disarmament In Colombia, ex-rebels are preparing to enter the peacetime economy. Otis (2017) Jun 20, states that: There are no guns in sight at a rebel camp in Guaviare, a state in south-central Colombia. Instead, some 500 former members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, wear civilian clothes and pass the time playing soccer and volleyball, while they wait to be reintegrated into society. Several women among them—who while fighting were forced to use birth control and have abortions—­are pregnant or nursing newborns. Another first: The ex-­guerrillas are having to think about how they’ll earn a living now that they’ve laid down their weapons. Raul Andrés Ballesteros, 33, who dropped out of junior high to join the FARC, says he plans to study technology and become a systems engineer. Faisuri Mendoza, 29, a 10-year veteran and a member of the Cubeo Indian tribe, dreams of becoming an anthropologist. When Colombia’s government signed a peace treaty with the FARC last fall, it meant more than an end to a 52-year conflict that left an estimated 220,000 people dead and forced more than 5 million civilians from their homes. It also meant 7,000 guerrillas would have a chance to disarm and enter the ­workforce. Whether Ballesteros, Mendoza, and the rest of their comrades find their bearings will go a long way toward determining the fate of Colombia’s peace process. Recruited as teenagers, many of the rebels are illiterate peasants who possess few skills beyond firing Kalashnikovs and patching up the wounded. Should they fail in their efforts to go back to school, find work, and organize a FARC-led political party—goals the Colombian government has pledged to support—they could once again return to the bush. Since the peace treaty was signed in September, more than 300 FARC guerrillas have broken ranks to form a dissident rebel group that’s attacking army troops and shaking down business owners. The dismantling of the FARC’s war machine began in January, when its fighters moved to about two dozen camps on government-leased land, where they’re gradually disarming under the supervision of United Nations monitors. Once that process finishes later this summer, rebels who have cleared police background checks will be free to start their new lives (para. 1-4). Otis, J. (2017). For Hire: 7,000 Former FARC Guerrillas. Bloomberg. Retrieved from
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2017-06-20/what-do-you-do-when-guerrilla-is-the-only-thing-on-your-r-sum

FARC rebels deliver another 30% of their weapons — leaving a total 60%: UN Volckhausen (2017) June 13, states that: As part of an ongoing peace process with the Colombian government, the FARC rebel group surrendered another 30% of its weapons cache Tuesday, leaving a total 60% of its weapons stockpile in the hands of the UN. The UN’s peacekeeping mission in Colombia confirmed the FARC had turned over their weapons by the early afternoon over Twitter. Taking place two days ahead of schedule, the weapons handover meets the second deadline of three in a disarmament process that will leave the FARC as an unarmed organization in a week’s time. The UN now has 4,406 arms, used by the FARC in over 50 years of armed conflict with the Colombian state, under its custody. According to RCN Radio, the UN monitors said the weapons are in good condition. The FARC turned over the first 30% of it’s weapons stockpile last week, meeting the first of three deadlines. The final deadline is scheduled for June 20 when they will turn over the rest of the 7,000 weapons to UN peace monitors. By September 1, all the FARC’s former arms must be removed from the demobilization, disarmament and reintegration (DDR) camps (para.1-7). Volckhausen, T. (2017). FARC rebels deliver another 30% of their weapons — leaving a total 60%: UN. Colombia Reports Retrieved from

Starting off with conservative estimates while I research further. As of now, the FARC has turned in 30% of its arms, and has extended its deadline for the next 30% until June 20. Complete disarmament is a prerequisite for establishing a political party. A recent arrest of a rebel in violation of the peace agreement is also creating obstacles between the FARC and the government. (http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-40197026) The FARC may be inclined to delay further if it perceives it has leverage over the government. (http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-40155871) Assuming the FARC can meet the June 20 deadine without another extension, the next deadline for it is the March 2018 Congressional elections (FARC stated it will not participate in the Presidential election as a political party - https://colombiareports.com/farc-says-wont-take-part-colombias-2018-presidential-elections/). While seats in the Congress are being reserved (https://colombiareports.com/colombia-peace-talks-in-depth/) and current political parties in Congress cannot run for them, the FARC will likely still want to get its candidates' names out there. Additionally, the peace process is not exactly popular among Colombians, and will likely be a main issue in 2018 (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/democracy-post/wp/2017/05/18/colombias-rebels-are-losing-patience-with-peace/). Thus, it would benefit the FARC to get established sooner rather than later to counter the anti-FARC narrative. Finally, the FARC has asked the Finance Ministry for $1.2M for funding its political party as soon as disarmament is completed (https://colombiareports.com/colombia-provide-initial-funding-farcs-political-party/). This would seem to indicate that the FARC would transition sooner than later. However, the final deadline for complete disarmament is September 1 and the FARC has indicated it will need another 2 months from the end of May (http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Colombias-FARC-Celebrates-Last-Anniversary-with-Arms-Warns-Disarmament-Will-Take-2-More-Months-20170528-0014.html).  For this reason, I'm hedging towards after October 1. Historically, it took the FARC 7 months to establish a political party in the 1980s with the Unión Patriótica under the bilateral ceasefire (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patriotic_Union_(Colombia) ), at which time the FARC had significantly more popularity among Colombians. With the initial steps taken to establish a party in December 2016, and a requirement to turn in all arms by September 1, I think it will be challenging for the FARC to establish a party before September 30.
